Programming Session 9

25 September 2016

Arrays!

Another part of most programming languages that I don‚Äôt really like, but have to learn and master anyway. Luckily, every time I review it, I end up understanding it a little bit more.

This time, I learned about push/pop, unshift/shift, and all the other interesting array methods that exist out there. Most textbooks or courses usually don‚Äôt cover these until way later, after I‚Äôve already given up on them. Cole Steele also covered basic nested arrays, which are surprisingly easy once you get used to them.

Next up was creating a small to-do list web application. After learning about what it should be able to do, I was easily able to create most of it myself. The only part I stumbled upon was how to get the web application to remember the new to-dos that I put into the variable ‚Äúlist‚Äù. Going through the solutions video made me realize that if you‚Äôre going to prompt the user for input repeatedly, you‚Äôre going to need to ask once outside the loop and one more time at the very end, inside the loop. My finished code ended up like this:

Remember anonymous functions? Yeah, they‚Äôre back for array iterations‚Ä¶ or in simpler words, array loops. As usual, I don‚Äôt enjoy them, but now I can see how useful they‚Äôd be on my future blog, especially when combined with the forEach function.

Applying it to the to-do list web application turned out to be surprisingly simple. Without listening to Cole Steele‚Äôs explanation, I was able to make it function mostly by myself, with only a little research on how to remove an array item. The way I went about deleting a to-do item differs from his, but it achieves the same result:

Alright, that‚Äôs it for today. Got school tomorrow.
